Specifiche esperienze professionali cara.content: 2008, Consulenza e collaborazione con Dr. L. Quintana-Murci, Human Evolutionary Genetics, CNRS, URA3012, Department of Genomes & Genetics Center of Bioinformatics, Biostatistics and Integrative Biology, Istituto Pasteur, Parigi, per ricerche interdisciplinari su DNA afro-asiatici grazie agli studi condotti su più aree e su più gruppi di popolazioni nella storia dell'Oceano Indiano. The "Human Evolutionary Genetics" Unit focuses on the different factors (selective, demographic, and genomic) shaping the variability of the human genome. Their research activities are concentrated on the study of the genetic and functional diversity of genes involved in immune response or host-pathogen interactions. Using an evolutionary approach, their aims are (i) to explore the extent to which infectious agents have exerted selective pressures on human genes, (ii) to identify the genes having played a major biological role in host survival, and (iii) to delineate the redundant and non-redundant role of immunity-related genes in the natural setting. Their ultimate goal is to define the natural variability of host responses to infection in the human model and to understand the extent to which this phenotypic variation is under genetic and epigenetic control. To do so, their laboratory combines different approaches including population genetics, cellular genomics (transcriptomics and proteomics), immunology as well as computational modelling and development of new statistical frameworks. Papers: B. Nicolini, 2006, The Makran-Baluch-African Network in Zanzibar and East Africa during the XIX century, “African & Asian Studies”, Brill Academic Publishers, Leiden, vol. 5, n. 3-4, pp. 347-370. ISI Web of Science - SCOPUS - http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/br ill/afas/2006/00000005/f0020003/art00005 ; B. Nicolini, 2007, The Baluch Role in the Persian Gulf during the 19th and 20th centuries, “Comparative Studies of South Asia, Africa and the Middle East”, University of Toronto, Ontario, Canada, vol. 27, n. 2, pp. 384-396. http://cssaame.dukejournals.org/content/27/2/384.full.pdf Papers quoted by: Black, M.L., Sinha, S., Agarwal, S., Colah, R., Das, R., Bellgard, M., Bittles, A.H., A descriptive profile of β-thalassaemia mutations in India, Pakistan and Sri Lanka (2010) “Journal of Community Genetics” September; 1(3): 149–157. doi: 10.1007/s12687 -010-0026-9. Pubmed Central PMCID: PMC3185991 (source Scopus).
2014, Consulenza e collaborazione Ibadi Studies Group, H. Gaube; E. Staples; A. Al Salimi; F. Ersilia. http://ibadi-studies.org

2016, Incarico per la supervisione del progetto, per la stesura di testi e per ricerche del film project: The Sons of Sinbad. The Legacy of Omani Civilization in East Africa: The Call of Zanzibar, Demax GMBH Film Production Services, Monaco di Baviera, Germania.

2016, Richiesta di traduzione in lingua araba da parte della casa editrice Al Jadawel Publishing & Distribution Co., Riyadh, Regno dell'Arabia Saudita del volume Makran, Oman and Zanzibar, Brill, Leiden, 2004.

Responsabilita' scientifica per progetti.content: 2004-5, Progetto ex Murst 40% L’Oceano Indiano e il mare Arabico: Società tradizionali e loro trasformazioni (XVI-XX secolo), Bando D.1., Università Cattolica, Milano, 24 mesi.

Taddia, Università degli Studi di Bologna, 24 mesi, Titolo: Attraversamenti di Memorie, di Identità e di Confini. Verso un'analisi transnazionale della storia coloniale e post-coloniale: il caso del Corno d'Africa. Il ruolo delle risorse umane nella ricostruzione degli stati del Corno d’Africa.
